dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Eurail rolls along. Inside, passengers sleep, read, a stare out the windows. A few walk up and down the aisles. CELINE, a young woman in her mid-twenties, is curled up i her seat reading Georges Bataill’s Story of the Eye. Strikingly attractive, she plays it down by wearing no makeup, a loose-fitting vintage dress, and flat shoes. Sh continues reading while taking an occasional bite of a chocolate bar. Sitting four rows back and on the other si of the aisle, JESSE, also mid-twenties, is engrossed in K Kinski’s memoir, All I Need Is Love. Casually good lookin but a little scruffy, he dresses in the jeans and T-shirt mode. Suddenly a couple, two fortyish types who have been arguing semiquietly in the seat behind Celine, start yell at each other in German. The WIFE takes a swipe at the newspaper the HUSBAND has been screening him behind.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Will you put down that damn newspaper and listen to me?

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: What’ve I been doing the last thirty minutes? Would you shut up for Chrissake?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: You shut up! How dare you tell me to shut up! It’s the same damn thing all over again! I can’t believe --

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: I said shut up! I’m putting down my newspaper and telling you to shut up. Celine suddenly gets up, grabs her bag, and starts lookin for another seat. A few rows back, she finds a seat acros the aisle from Jesse. Before sitting down, they make brie eye contact and kind of shake their heads and smile at th tension. Just as she settles in and goes back to her book the wife gets up and storms down the aisle. Jesse and Cel follow her with their eyes, and as she passes them, they they are looking right at each other. He makes a funny “u oh” face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what they’re arguing about? Do you speak English?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. But no, I don’t know. My German is not that good. (a beat) Have you ever heard that as couples get older they lose their ability to hear each other?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Supposedly men lose their ability to hear higher-pitched sounds and women eventually lose hearing on the low end. I guess they sort of nullify each other or something.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Must be nature’s way of allowing couples to grow old together and not kill each other, I guess. There’s a slightly awkward moment where they don’t know i they should continue talking or not. She glances back dow at her book but he keeps looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you reading? She holds up the book so he can see what it is.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How about you? He shows her what he’s reading. Neither has much to say about the other’s reading material.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are so many weird people on the train, no? Last week on my way to Budapest I was sitting and talking with four other people in the lounge car and it turned out that three of them had killed people.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. One was a war veteran, one had murdered her boyfriend, and another had caused a bad car wreck.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you were the only one who hadn’‘t killed anyone?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I was one of them. Which one do you think? She laughs and he slowly joins her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. I’ve met some weirdos. There was this British guy sitting across from me the other day who kept throwing his body against the back of his chair, yelling about how we should all join together and stop the train. He was saying, “Everybody, now, we can stop technology. All together...”

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So what happened? He demonstrates by throwing his body against his seat.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And you know, me and a few others tried for a while, but we couldn’t stop technology. The wife who stormed away earlier suddenly comes back and argument resumes, right in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was thinking about going to the lounge car sometimes soon. You wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We better. They get up and walk to the door of their car. He pushes DOOR OPEN button, and as the door opens, he extends his h toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m Jesse. It’s James, actually, but my whole life everyone’s called me Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So it’s Jesse James?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, just Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Celine. They proceed through the door and Celine pushes the DOOR button to enter the next car. There is some confusion as who is opening the door for whom before Celine proceeds a jesse follows her toward the lounge car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit at a table, eating chips and taking an occasiona swig from a drink.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So how do you speak such good English?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I went to school for a summer in Los Angeles and I’ve spent some time in London. How do you speak such good English?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m American.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. It’s a joke. I knew you were American, and, of course, you don’t speak any other language.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I’m the dumb, vulgar American who has no culture. But I tried. I want you to know I took four years of French. I tried, I was ready. When I was in Paris, I was standing in line at the metro going, “Un billet, s’il vous plait. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un billet, s’il vous plait.” And then I got up to the window, I looked up at the lady and blanked out. “Uh, uh, I need a ticket for the subway.” No more French for me. (a beat) So where are you headed?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Back to Paris. My class starts next week.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Where do you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: La Sorbonne. You know?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure. But you were in Budapest?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was visiting my grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. How about you - where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What’s there?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m flying out of there tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you on a holiday?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’m on. I’ve just been traveling around the last two or three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Were you visiting friends, or just going around on your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I visited a friend in Madrid for a while, but mostly I’ve just been... (new thought) I got one of those Eurail passes, and you know what’s fascinating about traveling around? You spend all this time trying to reach your destination, you get there, you look around, it’s never exactly what you’d hoped, you head off somewhere else, and hope for something better.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s like getting ready for a party, getting there, and falling asleep. That’s why when I’m traveling I kind of force myself not to expect anything from anywhere or anyone. And then, whatever happens is a surprise. The most insignificant thing can become an endless subject of interest, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s what I like about traveling - you can sit down, maybe talk to someone interesting, see something beautiful, read a good book, and that’s enough to qualify a good day. You do that at home and everyone thinks you’re a bum.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I like that though. But it’s like my favorite American writers. They describe everything you wouldn’t want to live through, and yet you cannot stop reading of this exciting, boring life.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So what do you study?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Literature. But I haven’t decided yet what I really want to do.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you want to write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but... (new thought) I kind of had this obsession a few years ago about creating a new form of expression. It was of course an abstract and lost quest, but I was feeling all art forms seemed used up. I was especially rejecting words. They seemed so rusted and dirty. And they’ve been used for such evil ends. Sometimes, you know, language is so limited. It’s like...if you think about it... She holds her hands out fairly wide and round.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is an individual’s mental experience and perception and... She holds her hands together and forms a small circle.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is how much can be expressed through language. We just don’t have words for so many of the impressions we have. She parts her hands and gestures to the large outer circl

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So most of our life we will never be able to express to anyone. They sit there for an extended moment, neither sure what say next. Suddenly Jesse smiles and jokingly starts to ge up.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So I guess...that’s it - it’s been nice not communicating with you. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Really, though, I basically agree with you, and maybe it’s a sad face of life, but I think it doesn’t bother me that much. Maybe I’m wrong about this, but I think that lack of communication frustrates women more than men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, because men are perfectly content to sit in front of TV all day drinking beer and watching sports.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s true, but have you ever done that? I did it once with a friend of mine. Drank some beer, had some chips, and watched a couple of games. It was the first time in years I literally jumped for joy. On some level it’s sticking your head in the sand, but on another I think it must serve some tribal purpose.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I actually agree with you. I kind of like sports. It’s one of these few times when men are treated like stupid objects...I’m joking. So you haven't told me what you do. Are you still in school?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nah, I never graduated from college.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you working?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I have a stupid job like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Is it boring? You’re not happy?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, it’s a decent job. I don’t get paid that much. I don’t do that much.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So what is the job?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I write for a newspaper, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, and pretty much get to do what I want there creatively, so it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you write?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Kinda.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So has this trip been good for you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, on one level, it sucked, but sitting on a train and staring out the window for days on end has actually been kind of great.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I've had an idea I probably would never have had otherwise. Can I tell you about it?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Some friends of mine are these cable access producers - you know, anyone can produce a program, and they have to show it. I got really jazzed about it. I imagined a show I want to produce that would last an entire year, twenty-four hours a day. I want to get 365 different video producers around the world to each make their own twenty-four- hour-long document of real time, capturing life around them just as it is lived. So it’d be people waking up, taking a long shower, getting a cup of coffee and reading the paper for twenty minutes, a long drive to work.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You mean all those boring, mundane things everyone has to do every day of their life?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was going to say the poetry of day-to-day life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, Why is your dog so great just for sleeping in the sun? And a guy getting money out of a bank machine is a moron?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you can put on the TV at any time of the day and see what other people are doing at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right. It’s like parallel lives.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's great. I once lived ina big apartment I was sharing with friends, and we could see ten other apartments from the window. I would cut down the light, sit at the window, and watch them sitting on a couch doing nothing. It was fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s the trick. Life is not really about drama. That we all do the same shit and going to some market in Arabia is the same as going to Kmart in Miami. People believe they are missing out, that everyone else has this great and exciting life and they don’t. I mean, we all have to get dressed, feed the kids, get our driver's licence renewed, look up what time the afternoon matinee starts, lose ourselves in entertainment, lose ourselves in sex, routine, getting a little too drunk, buying a present for someone you don’t like very much - you feel guilty about not liking them, so you spend a little too much money.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So, it’s like a National Geographic program on people.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Exactly.  11.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I can see it: twenty-four boring hours and a three-minute sex scene where he falls asleep right after.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Exactly. And that would be an exciting episode. Maybe you and your friends can do one of those episodes from Paris. The key to making this work would be in the distribution. Getting the tapes from town to town on time...But it would play continuously twenty-four hours for a year on stations around the world. The waiter finally arrives and gives them the menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some time has passed. They have dirty dishes in front of them. They seem more relaxed with each other, more forthright, less self-conscious, a little more intimate.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: My parents have never really spoken of the possibility of my falling in love or getting married or having children. Even as a little girl, they wanted me to think about a future career as a TV newscaster, or a dentist, or something like that.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Anchorwoman...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd say to my dad I wanted to be a writer and he’d say journalist. I'd say I wanted to have a refuge for stray cats and he'd say veterinarian. I'd say I wanted to be an actress and he’d say TV newscaster. It was this constant conversion of my fanciful ambitions into practical moneymaking ventures.  12.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Parents just want you to have a nice career so they can tell their friends something interesting. (a beat) I musta had a pretty decent bullshit detector when I was a kid. I always knew when they were lying to me. By the time I was in highschool, I was dead set on listening to what everyone thought I should be doing with my life and then almost systematically doing the opposite. They weren’t really mean about it. All their typical ambitions sounded so mediocre.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: If you have parents that never fully contradict anything you want to do and are basically nice and supportive, it makes it harder to officially complain. Even when they are wrong. It’s this passive- aggressive shit. I can’t stand it. Jesse takes a swig of water and chews some ice.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but despite plenty of bullshit, I still remember being a kid as a magical time. (a beat) I remember my mom explaining death to me, and telling me that my great-— grandmother in Florida had died. The whole family had just visited them. I must have been three, three and a half years old. Anyway, I was playing in the backyard a day or so later, and my sister had taught me how to spray the garden hose into the sun and see a rainbow. Well, I was spraying it and through the mist I could see my great-grandmother standing there, just kind of smiling, looking at me. I just held the hose in that position for a long time and looked at her. Finally, I took my thumb off the nozzle, let the hose go, and she disappeared. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My parents gave me this rap about how I imagined it and how when people die you never see them again. But, I knew what I had seen, and even though I’ve never seen anything like that since, I’ve never really been very afraid of death.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That’s good you can have that attitude toward death. I think I am afraid of death twenty-four hours a day. That’s why I’m on the train. I could have flown to Paris. I’m just afraid of flying. Even though statistics say it’s safer, I can’t help it. When I’m sitting in a plane, I already can see an explosion, me falling through the clouds. I’m so afraid of the few seconds of consciousness before dying. I mean, when you know for sure you’re gonna die. I can’t help anticipating the worst. Like, I was in the park with this friend of mine. There were little kids playing around. This mother was throwing her child up in the air. My friend was smiling and thought it was so wonderful, and all I could think of was her dropping it. I could already see all the blood on the ground. The big panic, the mother crying...I think like this all the time. It’s exhausting. We see out the window that the train is pulling into Vien

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Vienna. You get off here, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Drag. I wish I would have met you earlier. I really like talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It was really nice talking to you, too.  14.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I've hardly talked to anyone in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train comes to a final stop. The doors open and soon everyone is unboarding and boarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a slight smile, Jesse looks intensely at Celine.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I have an admittedly insane thought. If I don’t ask you this, it’ll be one of those things that will haunt me forever.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What? He just looks at her a little nervously and can’t say it. She is truly intrigued and a little excited at what he’s struggling with.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I want to keep talking with you. I mean, I have no idea what your situation is, but I feel some kind of...connection.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So how about this. Okay, good...I want you to get off her in Vienna with me. We can check out the town. She smiles at the thought but is not totally sure.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So what would we do?  15.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. All I know is I’m getting on this Austria Airlines flight at nine-thirty tomorrow morning and I can’t really afford a hotel and we'll probably just wander around all night. If I turn out to be a psycho, you can bail out anytime and get back on the next train, right? She's still thinking but doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think of it like this. Jump ahead ten, twenty years. Your marriage just doesn’t have that same energy anymore. You start to blame your husband. You think of all the guys you've met and all the ones you never pursued and how things might have been different if you’d just picked up with one of them. Well, I’m one of them. You can consider this traveling back in time, to see what you are missing. See, this is really a big favor to both you and your future husband - it’s a chance to see how you really haven’t missed anything. That I’m just as boring and unmotivated as he is, hopefully more. She smiles a little, ponders the situation, and then just stands up.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure if I got all the story, but let me get my bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets off the train with his bags and starts walking, n fully aware she’s not right behind him. She has hesitated slightly and pauses at the top of the stairs. After glanc back briefly, she looks ahead and proceeds with confidenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the busy train station lobby, they stop at a chang machine and exchange currency.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes putting his stuff in a locker. She opens a locker and stuffs her bag in.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what this makes me think of?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: All those people you briefly intersect with, maybe make eye contact with, and then pass by.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes, we could have done that. Now it’s like...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No matter what happens, we have met. Jesse just smiles and offers up his open hand. She touche her hand to his and there is a slow clasp and a slight pu toward one another.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That we have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking along in silence, they both are observing what is around them and eventually look back at each other. Fully realizing they are now committed to one another in some strange way, there is an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s such a strange feeling. When we were talking on the train, it’s like we were in public - there were people around us. Now that we’re actually walking around Vienna, it’s like we are all alone.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. It feels a little awkward. I’m not sure what we should be doing. He puts his hand on her shoulder and looks right at her.  17.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But this is okay, though, right?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, this is great. Let’s go to some places. Look at your little book. He pulls out a little pamphlet/map and starts looking thr it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good. Right. We're in Vienna and we're going to go places. Just then two local passersby, TEX and KARL, walk past th Jesse stops them.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Sprechen Sie English?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Yah, of course.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Perhaps you speak German for a change?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: It was a joke. Tex looks over at Karl, both in on it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We just got into Vienna and we're looking for something fun to do...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, are there any museums we should see or anything?

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Museums are not exactly fun these days. Karl looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: And they are all closing right now, anyway. How long are you going to be here?  18.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just tonight.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Why did you come to Vienna? What could you be expecting?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We’re on our honeymoon...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s pregnant, so we decided to go ahead and get married.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. You are not very good at lying. Celine and Jesse laugh while Tex and Karl talk amongst themselves in German.

dialogues.speaker: TEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have the fliers?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l give them one. Karl digs in his pocket and hands a flier to them.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: This is a play we’re both in we’d like you to come to.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you are actors?

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Not professional actors, but part- time for fun.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: It’s a play about a cow, and an Indian searching for it. It also has politicians, Mexicans, Russians...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You have a real cow onstage?

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Not a real cow. It’s an actor ina cow costume.  19.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: And he’s the cow.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m the cow. But it’s a weird cow.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: The cow has a disease.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: She's acting a bit strange...acting like a dog. If someone throws a stick, she fetches it. She also smokes, with her hoofs. He demonstrates how one would smoke with a hoof instead o hand. Karl points to the bottom of the flier.

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: The address is on the flier. It’s in the second district...

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: Near the Prater...

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Yes, the place with the big Ferris wheel.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: The big wheel everybody knows...

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you can go to the Prater before the play.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So what's the name of this play?

dialogues.speaker: KARL
dialogues.text: It translates as...

dialogues.speaker: BOTH
dialogues.text: “Bring Me the Horns of Wilmington’s Cow.”

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Cool.  20. Tex puts his index finger up by his head as everyone begi to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: TEX
dialogues.text: I am the cow...and you will be there?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We'll try to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on a bench near a statue, looking up at the hist buildings and surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Look at this - it’s beautiful. I mean, could you imagine an American architect saying, “Hey, Bob, I’ve got an idea. Why don’t we put a giant angel on top of this building just for people to have something beautiful to look at.” It might start out like that, but before too long it'd be, “Sorry, Hank, boss said nix on the giant angel. He’s thinking more along the lines of a flagpole.”

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Americans always think Europe is perfect. But such beauty and history can be really oppressive. It reduces the individual to nothing. It just reminds you all the time you are just a little speck in a long history, where in America you feel like you could be making history. That’s why I liked Los Angeles because it is so...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ugly?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I was going to say “neutral.” It’s like looking at a blank canvas. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think people go to places like Venice on their honeymoon to make sure they are not going to fight for the first two weeks of their marriage because they’1l be too busy looking around at all the beautiful things. That’s what people call a romantic place - somewhere where the prettiness with contain your primary violent instinct. A real good honeymoon spot would be like somewhere in New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come down the escalator and board a tram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sitting in the tram and observing everything goi by.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, Q&A time. We’ve known each other for a little while now, we’re stuck with each other, we can ask each other a few, you know, direct questions.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So we ask each other questions?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And you have to answer one hundred percent honestly.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Of course. Celine picks up on the game he is talking about.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: First question. Describe your first sexual feelings toward someone.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, let me think...Jean-Marc Fleury.  He thinks 22.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Jean-Marc Fleury?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We were at this summer camp together and he was a swimmer. He had that bleached-out, chlorine hair and green eyes, and to improve his times, he’d shave the hair off his legs and arms. So he was like this gorgeous dolphin. My friend Emma had a big crush on him, and one day I was cutting across the field on my way back to my room, he came walking up beside me. I told him he should ask Emma out because she had a big crush on him, and he said, “That’s too bad, because I have a big crush on you.” And it really scared the hell out of me because I thought he was so fine. He officially asked me out on a date but I pretended that I didn’t like him because I was afraid of what I might do. But I went toa swim competition and watched him swimming around. He was so sexy. At the end of the summer we sort of wrote these little declarations of love to each other and said we would keep writing and for sure meet again soon.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I think then this is the appropriate time to tell you I happen to be an excellent swimmer.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l make a note, but it’s my turn to ask a question. Have you ever been in love? for a bit and then starts in.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes. Okay, next question. What do you think is you --  23.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. We can give on-word answers?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: After I went into such detail about my first sexual feelings?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But there's a big difference between those two things. I could tell you all about my first sexual feelings, no big deal. What if I asked you about love?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I would have lied, but at least I would've made a great story.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: See. The whole concept of love is much more complex. Love’s like God or something: It’s everywhere...I see it, I feel it, but I don’t know if another person is going to hand it to me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: For what it’s worth, my first sexual feelings were experienced through an obsessive relationship with Miss July, 1978. You know Playboy?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, name something that really pisses you off.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, gosh, everything pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Like what?  24.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I hate being told by strange men to smile, just to make them feel better about their stupid lives. I hate that three hundred kilometers away a war is going on. People are dying. And nobody knows what to do about it. I hate how the media tries to control our minds. It’s a new form of very subtle fascism. And I hate in a foreign country each time I wear black or lose my temper or express an opinion about anything, everyone always goes: “Oh, it’s so French, it’s so cute.” Oh, I hate that. They both laugh a bit at her becoming riled up so quickly She calms down and asks him a question.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s my turn now. So what’s a problem for you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You, probably.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, really, I had a thought about a week ago that’s kind of a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you believe in reincarnation?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: On some level it’s interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It seems like a lot of people are talking about past lives and all that. And even if you don’t believe in that in a specific way, most people have some notion of an eternal soul, right? Anyway, my thought was, if we all have our origins at the beginning of human history in some way, where did all the current souls come from? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The earth’s population fifty thousand years ago was not even a million people. Ten thousand years ago, it was only a few million. Now, the earth’s population is between five and six billion. That’s about a five-thousand-to-one split of each soul in just the last fifty thousand years, which is just a blip in the earth’s time. At best, we’re just a tiny fraction of a soul. Is that why we all feel so scattered?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So, that’s a problem?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, it’s kind of a scattered thought, which is all the more reason it makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the old, vinyl-only store and start to browse.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Is that a listening booth over there?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so. They keep looking through albums. She eventually finds an album and holds it up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of this singer?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (reading) No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I think she’s American. I have this friend in LA who told me about her. I’ve never been able to find any of her stuff. I think it’s kind of folksy, lyrical stuff. Jesse points across the store.  14 15 26.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Lets’ see if that listening booth works.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Let’s try it. They walk over to the booth and enter. She takes the albu out and puts it on the turntable. As the music starts the both kind of lean against opposite walls in the small gla booth and concentrate on the song.

dialogues.speaker: SONG
dialogues.text: There’s a wind that blows in from the north And it says that loving takes its course Come here, come here No, I’m not impossible to touch I have never wanted you so much Come here. Come here... They glance subtly up at each other but usually not when other is looking. The song makes both of them a little nervous as it brings out a shyness about the uncertainty their relationship at that point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride on a subway as it breaks out of a tunnel into sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk down the steps toward the small cemetery. A rab runs past them.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I visited this as a young teenager. It left a bigger impression on me at that time than any of the museums we went to.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It’s small. Inside, they wander around looking at the mostly identica crosses.  27.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. There was this little old man who talked to us. He was the groundskeeper. Almost everyone buried here washed up on the bank where the Danube curves away.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How old are these?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Around the beginning of the century or so. It’s called Cemetery of the No Name because they often didn’t really know who these people were. Maybe a first name.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why were there so many bodies washing up on the banks of the Danube?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I think some were from accidents on boats and things like that, but most of them were suicides that jumped in the river. (a beat) I always liked the idea of all these unknown people, lost in the world. When I was young I always thought that if none of your family or friends knew you were dead, then it’s like not really being dead. People can invent the best or the worst for you. She stops by one grave.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, here she is. This is the one I remember the most. She was thirteen when she died. That meant something to me because I was that age when I saw this. Now I’m ten years older and she’s still...thirteen, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage shot of them riding on the tram at dusk.  17 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in the huge old Ferris wheel in the Prater amuse park. They have a large box to themselves and walk around it looking at the various views.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: When I’m up above everyone like this, I always think like the entire human race is this body, and we're all cells in the body. It’s an amazing, exquisite mess, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah... (a beat) I want to change the subject for a second. This could be an important moment. I don’t know if you noticed, but we’re alone in this car. The sun is going down... (a beat) Before the night is over, is it safe to assume that we’re going to kiss?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Maybe?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Probably. Then I propose we jump in time to that moment when we would naturally do that - probably a couple of hours from now after a certain amount of awkwardness and stuff - and bring that moment back to here and now, given these ideal surroundings. It’ll be a great way to remember not only our first kiss, but this great sunset, the Ferris wheel, Vienna... Celine walks over to him and puts her arms around his nec

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How come every time you want me to do something, you start talking about time travel?  29.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, I think we should kiss right now. They begin kissing and the Ferris wheel keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking along, they are in mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But I don’t think it matters what generation you’re born into. Look at my parents. They were these angry young May ‘68 people revolting against everything - the government, their conservative Catholic backgrounds. I was born not long after and my dad went on to become this successful architect and we began to travel all over the world and I was raised with all the freedoms they had fought for. And yet for me now, it’s another type of fight. We still have to deal with all the same shit. But you can’t really know what or who the enemy is.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know if there is an enemy. Everyone’s parents fucked them up. They either left them or stuck around and taught them the wrong stuff. Rich kids’ parents give them too much, poor kids’ not enough. You either get too much attention or not enough. My parents are just these two people who didn’t like each other very much who got married and had a kid. And they tried to be nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Did your parents divorce?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, finally. They should have done it earlier, but they stuck together for the well-being of my sister and me. Thanks. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, my mom once told me, right in front of my father when they were in this big fight, that he was really, really pissed off when he found out she was pregnant with me - that I was this big mistake. Looking back on it, I think that shaped the way I think. I saw the world as this place I wasn’t really meant to be and had the people who created me had more control of the situation, I wouldn’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But that’s so sad.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I think I eventually found a comfort in that. Like my life was my own doing or something.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: My parents are still together and I think they’re happy. But I think it’s a healthy process to rebel against your parents and everything that came before. In a certain way, more than rebelling, it’s to have the feeling that we’re finding a new way to deal with love, sex, society, everything. We should always have to reinvent and make it our own. They walk in silence, just taking in all around them for few moments. A couple walks by, but both are completely i their own worlds.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been wondering lately...do you know anyone who’s in a happy relationship?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know happy couples, but it seems like they have to lie to each other.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: People can live their whole life as a lie. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My grandmother was married to this man, and I always thought she had a very simple, uncomplicated love life. But she just confessed to me that she spent her life dreaming about another man she was always in love with. She just accepted her fate. I was so sad. But I also found it very beautiful that she had all those emotions I never thought she would have had.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I guarantee you that it was better that way. Had she got to know him, he would have disappointed her eventually.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How do you know? You don’t know who they are.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. It’s just people have all these romantic projections.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Mr. Romantic up in the Ferris wheel kiss me now as the sun is going down...?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) All right, all right. What about your grandmother? Finish your thought.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It just amazed me that I’ve spent over twenty years of my life around her and I didn’t know her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know her, but no one really knows anyone. That’s the thing about relationships - people are always saying, “I want to know you, I want to know who you are.” But it is so hard for anyone to even know themselves. Who I am is always changing, so how can anyone else share in that?  19 32.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So that’s it? It’s been nice not knowing you. They look over and see several elderly couples riding the bumper cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sitting at a table in a sparsely populated outdo café. Jesse looks around briefly and then suddenly leans over and kisses a slightly surprised Celine.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to kiss you again. Celine sort of smiles and shrugs her shoulders when a ROS PEDDLER suddenly approaches them. She is an older gypsy- looking woman and holds up her bunch of roses toward Jess

dialogues.speaker: ROSE PEDDLER
dialogues.text: (in German) You buy a rose for the young lady? Jesse smiles and digs in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure, how many schillings?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE PEDDLER
dialogues.text: Twenty. As Jesse hands her the coins and she gives him the rose, suddenly turns all her attention to Celine. She impulsive grabs her hand and intensely starts looking at her palm. ROSE PEDDLER (CONT’D) You want your palm read?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sure. Celine looks over at Jesse, who rolls his eyes, feeling a little invaded. She flashes him a “I want to do this, don spoil it” look.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE PEDDLER
dialogues.text: Hmmm. Uhh-huuh. So you have been on a journey and you are a stranger to this place. You are an adventurer...a seeker...and adventurer in your mind.  33. Celine is engrossed and occasionally nods. ROSE PEDDLER (CONT’D) You are interested in the power of the woman. In a woman’s deep strength and creativity. You are becoming this woman. (a beat) You need to resign yourself to the awkwardness of life. Only if you find peace within yourself will you find true connections with others. The rose peddler looks up at Jesse and gestures to him. ROSE PEDDLER (CONT’D) This is a stranger to you, yes?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, I guess. The rose peddler authoritatively reaches for Jesse’s hand which he awkwardly offers up. She examines his hand thoroughly, flips it over, examines his thumb, and lets h take it back.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE PEDDLER
dialogues.text: (to Celine) You'll be alright (a beat) He is learning. (a beat) Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Thank you. That was good. Celine gets up and hands the woman several coins. As she walks away, the older lady adds one last bit.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE PEDDLER
dialogues.text: You are both stars, don’t forget. When the stars exploded billions of years ago, they formed everything that is this world. The moon, the trees, everything we know is stardust. So don’t forget. You are stardust. They walk away, and Celine is filled with the experience Jesse looks a little annoyed. The more he builds up to a rant, the more amused she seems to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s all nice and everything, we are stardust and all that, and you are becoming this great woman, but I hope you don’t think that’s much different than reading your horoscope in some syndicated daily paper.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, she knew I was on vacation and that we didn’t know each other and that I was going to become this great woman.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) And what was that “I am learning” bullshit? That's waaay condescending - she wasn’t even doing me, and I even bought that fucking rose from her. (starting rant) If opportunists like that would ever tell the real truth, it would put their asses out of business. (new thought) Just once I want to see some old lady save up her money, and just as she’s about to hear all this great stuff, the fortune teller would say, (wide-eyed stare) “Tomorrow and all your remaining days will be a lot like today, a tedious collection of hours. You will have no new passions, travels, or thoughts. When you die you will be forgotten. Two hundred schillings, please.” That I’d like to see. Celine plays with him.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So it’s funny how she almost didn’t notice you. I loved what she said.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Of course you do. You pay your money, you get to hear something that makes you feel good. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe there’s some seedy section of Vienna where you can buy a hit of crack. Celine continues to laugh at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they are walking, Celine notices a poster for an upcom exhibit of Seurat’s drawings.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, man, this doesn’t start until next week - we’ll miss it. She motions to one of the drawings on the poster.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I actually saw this one at a museum a few years ago. I just stared and stared at it - must have been forty- five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I love the way the people seem to be dissolving into the background. It’s like the environments are stronger than the people. His human figures always seem so transitory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk down the street, they wander up the steps to large cathedral. They check to see if the door is open. I is, and they go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter to find it completely empty but with hundreds candles still burning. In the background we hear the soun of the organ being tuned.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Too bad it isn’t daytime so we could see the stained glass windows better.  36.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I was in an old church like this one with my grandmother in Budapest a few days ago. Even though I reject most of the religious thing, I can’t help but feeling for all those people that come here lost, or in pain, guilt - who come here looking for answers. It fascinates me how a single place can join so much pain and happiness, for so many generations.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you’re pretty close to your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so. I think it’s because I’ve always had this feeling that I’m this very old woman, laying down, about to die, and her last thoughts are the remembrance of her youth and her life. I feel like my life is just her memories or something.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's wild. I always feel like I’m still this thirteen-year-old boy who doesn’t really know how to be an adult. So it’s like I’m pretending to live a life, taking notes for when I’1l really have to do it. Kind of like a dress rehearsal for a junior high play.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's funny. So up there in the Ferris wheel it was this very old woman kissing this very young boy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Get your head out of the gutter. (new thought) Do you know anything about the Quakers?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, not much.  37.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It’s really cool. I went to this Quaker wedding once, and do you know how they do it? The couple kneels down in the middle of the church in front of everyone, and they stare at each other. Nobody speaks unless God moves them to say something - a blessing, a warning, nothing, whatever. And then after an hour of staring into each other’s eyes, they’re married.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That’s beautiful. I like that. They stare at each other for an extended moment. He sudde has a new thought and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Gosh, this is kind of a horrible story, but maybe this is an appropriate place to tell it. I was driving around with this buddy of mine who’s this big atheist, and we came to a stop where there was this homeless guy holding up a sign saying he needed a job or something. My friend holds out a hundred-dollar bill to him and asks, “Do you believe in God?” The guy looks at him, looks at the money, and says, “Yes, I do.” My friend goes, “Wrong answer,” and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That’s so mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rain falls, they run for cover, finding a seat und huge umbrella in an outdoor café.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Would you be in Paris yet if you hadn’t gotten off the train?  38.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, not yet. And what would you be doing?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know - hanging out at the airport, reading old magazines, crying in my coffee because you wouldn't get off the train with me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Abh... She gives him a little kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually, I'd probably have gotten off the train in Salzburg with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. I’m just that American decorating your blank canvas.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no. I’m having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Really? Me too.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm glad. I love this because no one knows I’m here and I don’t know anyone that knows you that would tell me all the bad things you’ve done.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I can tell you some.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I’m sure. You hear so much shit about people. When I start dating a guy, I always feel like a general in the army - you know, plotting my strategy and maneuverings, knowing his weak points, what would hurt him, seduce him... (a beat) But if we were around each other all the time, what would be the first thing about me that would drive you crazy?  39.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to answer that. I dated this girl once who used to always ask me that. Finally, I told her that I thought that she didn’t handle criticism very well. Then she flew into a rage and broke up with me. But I think she really just wanted the chance to say what she thought was wrong with me. So just tell me what it is about me that bugs you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, there’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Tell me. C’mon, what?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I can’t think of anything.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m demanding you say something.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Actually, if I think about it, I didn’t like this kind of behavior back at the palm reader. You were like this little rooster prick.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Rooster prick? What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, you were like this little child whining because all the attention wasn’t focused on him.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? This woman robs you blind...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You were acting like a little boy walking by an ice cream shop, crying because his mother wouldn't buy him a milk shake or something.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wait a second. I didn’t care what this flower-peddling charlatan had to say about anything.  40. A man, the HOMELESS POET, approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS POET
dialogues.text: (in German) I'd like to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Uh, I speak okay, but he doesn’t at all.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS POET
dialogues.text: (in English) Okay, then. I’d like to make a deal with you guys. Instead of just asking for money, I’1l ask you for a word. I will then write a poem in which that word will be used. I’11 write it in English. If you like it, if you feel it adds something to your life in any way, then you can pay me whatever you feel like.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE AND JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, it’s a deal.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS POET
dialogues.text: Pick a word.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Uhh... (to Celine) What word?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Milk shake. Jesse flashes her a look.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was going to say “rooster prick.” But perfect, of course, milk shake. The poet walks off a ways and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I like what he said about adding something to your life.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. Hey, were we just arguing back there?  41.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think we were.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Even if we were, why does everyone think conflict is so bad? Good things can come out of conflict.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I guess so. I think if I could just accept the fact that life is supposed to be difficult, and that’s what’s to be expected, then I wouldn't get so pissed off about it. I’d just be happy when something nice happened.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I think That’s why I’m still in school. It’s easier to have something to fight against.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And we've all had this competitiveness drilled into us. (thinking) I mean, I can be doing the most nothing thing - shooting pool or playing darts socially - and I’1l feel it come over me: I want to win, I want to do the best I can, and my standards suddenly shift to just beyond my abilities. I can hear every coach or male teacher or boss I ever had. “Jesse, you're not trying hard enough! Get your head out of your ass! Hustle up!”

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Is that why you tried to get me off the train? Competitiveness?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: To make sure the guy behind you didn’t pick me up? Where you competing with him?  42.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That really cute, big, strong, Italian-looking guy two seats behind you that was smiling at me the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He’s better-looking than me? The homeless poet returns with a small piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (to Jesse) C'est la vie.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS POET
dialogues.text: I have your poem.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Will you read it to us?

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS POET
dialogues.text: Sure. (reads poem) Daydream delusion limousine eyelash Oh baby with your pretty face drop a tear in my wineglass Look at those big eyes on your face see what you mean to me Sweet cakes and milk shakes I’m a delusion angel I’m a fantasy parade I want you to know what I think don’t want you to guess anymore You have no idea where I came from we have no idea where we're going Lodged in life like branches in a river flowing downstream caught in the current I’ll carry you you carry me that’s how it could be don’t you know me don’t you know me by now They are both silent.  43.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wow... They give him some money.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was beautiful. You know, he didn’t just write that poem...I’m not saying he didn’t write that poem. He just didn’t write it tonight. He just plugged in that milk shake.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s a nice poem. They walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue walking along.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I want to ask you something. Do you consider me detached?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Detached from what?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Someone once called me this detached intellectual. I’m afraid I am like that. I comment too much on thing and maybe don’t feel close enough to anything.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t feel that way about you at all. Whoever said that is an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, but it’s my biggest fear. To be one of those people with that sort of academic, liberal, detached view of everything. That whole attitude has nothing to do with really living.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Who’s to say what’s really living?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, I wonder. That’s the big question, no? I think it’s either a life experienced or a life examined. But life examined is life experienced. (a beat) Maybe if I had none of these stupid artistic pretensions at all, I would be looking at the world differently.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What’s that Thomas Mann quote? “TI would rather participate in life than write a hundred stories.”

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hmmm, I like that. (a beat) I knew this guy once, this kind of nerdy goth-rock guy. And he was crossing the street one day, and he got hit by a car. We all went to see him in the hospital, and he was going to be okay and everything, but he told us that his strongest sensation from the accident was the joy he felt when he realized that finally something was actually happening to him. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s like seeing yourself from a third-person perspective. I always feel like I’m observing my life instead of living it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At my grandfather’s funeral, even though I loved him, it seemed everyone else was mourning and I was too busy observing them; each of them was like a paragraph of a book I might write someday, describing every emotion in detail.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. I remember when I was younger listening to my parents fight and feeling like I was in an after-school special on TV. Thinking I should act moody, or depressed. I should steal some cigarettes and sunglasses, get caught, and then blame it on the fact that I come from a troubled home.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think I’m always so much more happy with books and movies and stuff. I think I get more excited about well-done representations of life than life itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up to Viennese hot dog stand and order somethin drink. They notice some of the interesting characters hanging around, including the man behind the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter an interesting old café. Celine goes to the bathroom while Jesse waits. Separated from her for the fi time, he stands around a bit awkwardly, observing posters the goings-on in the café. She eventually returns and the exit the café.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in front of a bar/club from which there is musi coming out.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You want to go in?  29 46.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Is there a cover?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It’s cheap. I’11l pay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. I’ve got some cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SINGER with a guitar is onstage finishing up a weird bu humorous song. He finishes and gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: SINGER
dialogues.text: (in German) Hey, um, stick around. I think Liz is going to show her latest film and provide some verbal accompaniment. A projector is set up to show against the back wall of th stage. The filmmaker, LIZ, takes the microphone and sits the stage facing the screen. She has a piece of paper in hand and signals for the projectionist to start. The room darkens and the film begins. Behind the first black-and- white Super 8 images is the title scratched in white, in German: A KIND OF NOISE AND A KIND OF SILENCE. The film consists of images of fairly recent (1985-1994) events, b playing, catastrophes, televised images. Interspersed throughout is an eerie series of images of solitary individuals, some looking at the camera, some away. The f evokes a melancholy and almost romantic loneliness. She speaks in German and we read subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Our critique began, as all critiques begin, with doubt...doubt became our life. Ours was a quest for a new story, our own, and we grasped toward this new history, driven by the Dada suspicion that ordinary language could not tell it. (a beat) Our past appeared frozen in the distance and our every gesture and accent bespoke the negation of an old world and the reach for a new one. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The discovery of a true communication was what it was about - or at least the quest for such a communication, the adventure of finding it and losing it...we continued looking, the unappeased and the unaccepting, beneath, outside, dispersed, communicating only by a passing glance but still knowing that no matter how empty the world seemed, no matter how degraded and used up the world appeared to be, anything was still possible. Scratched on the film for a closing credit: TO BEGIN AGAI FROM THE BEGINNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are taking turns playing pinball.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So, we haven’t even talked about this, but, uh, are you dating anyone? You got a boyfriend waiting for you in Paris or anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, not right now...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We broke up over six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I mean, I’m not that sorry, but, uh, tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s boring. I can’t

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: C'mon, c'mon.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I was really disappointed. I thought this one would last a while. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was very stupid, ugly, bad in bed, alcoholic - I was kind of giving him a favor. But he left me saying I loved him too much and because I was blocking his artistic expression. I was traumatized and became totally obsessed with him. I went to see a shrink and it came up that I had written these little stories about how I was going to kill him - all the intricate details about how I would do it and not get caught.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Kill him? She realizes Jesse is looking at her a bit strangely.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh no, it’s nothing I would ever do, I think it was just some writing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Anyway, but this stupid shrink believed everything I was telling her. She said she had to call the police. She was totally convinced I was really going to do it even though I told her it was just my way of dealing with it. She said, looking deep into my eyes, “The way you said it, I know you are going to do it.” That was my first and last session. I totally got over him, but now I’m obsessed that he’s going to die from an accident, maybe a thousand kilometers away, and I will be accused. Jesse just smiles. They change positions and she begins playing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why is it you become obsessed with the people you don’t really care for? (a beat) So, what about you? Are you with anyone?  49.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Funny, how we avoided this question for so long.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know, but now you have to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Love is like this escape for people who haven’t learned to be alone or to make something of themselves. People think love is this unselfish or totally giving thing. But if you think about it, there’s probably nothing more selfish.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So who just broke up with you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sounds like you just got hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay...big confession. (a beat) Actually, I’11 tell you something. I didn’t just come to Europe to find myself and read Hemingway in Paris and shit like that. I worked all spring saving up money to fly to Madrid to spend the summer with my girlfriend, who’s been on this asinine art history program for the last year. But I got over here, and on our first night, reunited at long last, we went out to dinner, with five of her friends: Gonzalo, Pedro, Maria, Antonio, Suzie from home. She pretty much avoided being alone with me the first couple of days I was there, but I stuck around awhile just to let it sink in that she wished I hadn’t come. So I got the cheapest charter flight out of Europe, this one leaving out of Vienna tomorrow, but I had a couple of weeks to kill, so I bought a Eurail pass. (a beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what the worst thing about someone breaking up with you is? Remembering how little you really thought about the people you broke up with and realizing that’s how little they’re thinking about you. You like to think you are both in so much pain, but really they’re just relieved you're gone.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, you should look at bright colors.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That’s what that shrink told me. I was paying nine hundred francs an hour to hear that I was a homicidal maniac but I could perhaps shift my obsession if I would concentrate on bright colors.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I haven't killed him yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking along, they are engaged in an upbeat, lively deba

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I mean, why is a man ultimately judged so harshly on the issue of fidelity? You can be the best father and husband, you can be supportive and a great friend to your wife, but if you fuck around - uh-oh, we had it all wrong, you're really a loser. I mean, there are these breeds of monkeys, and all they do is have sex all the time. And they’re the ones that are the most peaceful and the most happy. What’s so bad about fooling around?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You're talking about monkeys?  51.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a perfect male argument for justifying them fooling around.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But the women monkeys are fooling around too.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know, I had this awful paranoid thought that feminism was mostly invented by men so they could fuck around more. Women, free your mind, free your body, sleep with me, we’re all free and happy as long as I can fool around as much as I want...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But think about it. If you had an island with ninety-nine women and one man, within a year you'd have the possibility of ninety-nine babies. If you had an island with ninety-nine men and one woman, after a year you’d have the possibility of one baby.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, and there’d probably be only about forty-three men left because they would have killed each other. And on the other island there would be ninety-nine women, ninety-nine babies, and no man because all the women would have gotten together and eaten him alive.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: There’s something to that, isn’t there? I think women don’t mind killing men on some level. Like, I was walking down the street once with my ex-girlfriend, and we pass these four thuggy guys leaning on a Camaro, and sure enough, one says, “Hey babe, nice ass.” I keep walking and I think, okay, have your fun, is it that big a deal? I don’t do anything. I let it slide...  32 52.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Plus there were four of them.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Exactly. So a few steps later, she turns and says, “Fuck you, dickheads.” I’m thinking, wait a minute, they aren’t going to come over and kick her ass. Who’s just been pushed to the front of the line on this one? See, women say they hate it when you get all territorial and protective, but when it suits them, they tell you you're being all unmanly and a wimp.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But I don’t think women want to kill men, and if they do, they rarely succeed. I’m sure men kill more women. Anyway, this is depressing. You know what?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Let’s stop talking about this.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. When you start talking about women and men, there’s no end.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know - it’s a skipping record. People have been trying to figure it out for millenniums. Every artist has tried their hand at it...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And no one’s come up with anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a series of tables of interesting people and hearin bits of conversations, we see Celine and Jesse sitting ac from each other, talking for once.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. Now I’m calling my best friend in Paris, who I’m supposed to have lunch with in about eight hours. Drrr! Drrr! Ring! Ring! Pick up.  53.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Pick up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Allo, Vani. C’est Celine. Comment ga va?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bien, et toi?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, tu sais ce qui n’est arrivé...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe we should do it in English.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Vanessa. I’m sorry I missed lunch, but I met a guy on the train and got off with him in Vienna. We're still here.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So he’s Austrian? He lives there?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, he’s just passing through here too. He’s American. He goes home tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So why’d you get off the train with him?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: He convinced me, but I think I was ready after only talking to hima short while. He was so sweet. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were in the lounge car and he began to talk about him as a little boy seeing his great-grandmother’s ghost. I think that’s when I feel for him - just the idea of this little boy, full of dreams. He trapped me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And he’s so cute. He has really beautiful blue eyes, nice pink lips, and greasy hair. He’s kinda tall and a little clumsy. I like to feel his eyes on me when I look away. And he kind of kisses like an adolescent. It’s so cute.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we kissed. It was so adorable. As the night went on I began to like him more and more. But I’m afraid he’s scared of me. I told him of my story about the woman killing her ex-boyfriend and stuff. He must be thinking I’m this manipulative, mean, dangerous woman. I just hope he doesn’t feel that way about me because - you know me - I’m the most harmless person. I just hide behind angriness because it’s the only way I’ve found to protect myself. The only person I could ever really hurt is myself.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I’m sure he’s not scared of you. I’m sure he’s crazy about you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, now it’s your turn. Call your friend. Jesse puts the phone up to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Brrriiing. I usually get this guy's answering machine.  55.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Hey, dude, what’s up?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hey, Frank, you’re there.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you're back? How was Madrid?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, it all pretty much sucked. I’m coming back a little early. Jodie and I finally had our long overdue meltdown. The long distance thing never seems to work, does it? All my stupid, romantic projections. Ugh. I was actually only in Madrid a few days. I had to get the hell out of there. I’ve been wandering around Europe for the last couple of weeks like an idiot. I got a cheaper flight out of Vienna that didn’t leave for a while, but it really wasn’t that much cheaper. I could have come right back, but I just couldn't. I think I wanted to just wallow for a while. I wanted to run, but not home. I didn’t want to see anyone I knew. I didn’t want to talk. I wanted to be a ghost, completely anonymous.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s just it. I’m great...rapturous. I’ma real person again. I’11 tell you why. It’s my last night in Europe and I’ve met someone very special. You know how they say we are each other’s angels and demons? Well, she was literally this Botticelli angel, waiting for me at the gate back to life.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wow...how did you meet?  33 56.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: On the train. I actually saw her a couple of hours before we ever talked, as I was finding a seat. She had her foot up on the seat across from her and didn’t notice me at all as I passed by her. Then later, there was this weirdo couple fighting near her, and she moved back and happened to sit right across the aisle from me. We began to talk. I don’t think she really liked me at the beginning. She is so smart and passionate and beautiful - I felt so unsure of myself. I felt everything I was saying was stupid macho stuff.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, man, I wouldn’t worry. I’m sure she was not judging you. And by the way, she decided to sit next to you. I’m sure she did it on purpose. Us men are stupid. We never understand women. They act strange, the little I know of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celine and Jesse sit on the steps of a statue and observe fairly constant activity around them. A serious-looking g walks by carrying a bag.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: See that guy? We’ll never see him again. That was the one moment our lives intersect. The guy suddenly turns and walks back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I always wonder about things like that. Like, think of the bag he is carrying. I wonder what is in it. If you think he’s carrying a bomb to blow up the opera because he failed his audition for Don Juan, then his serious expression becomes this angry, vicious face. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if you imagine in his bag is a present for his young, dying wife, then he becomes this poor, sympathetic character who you want to give a big hug to.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
