dialogues.text: Hmmm. Celine indicates a young art-student-looking woman.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: She's thinking about a TV show she saw yesterday on strippers, and even though all her friends were disgusted by it, she’s thinking about giving up her low-paying office job and giving it a try. A nerdy guy walks by.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That guy over there...rejected by Scientology. Actually flunked his free personality test - they had no use for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on the ledge overlooking the lit-up opera house.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I feel like this is some dream world we're walking through.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s so weird. It’s like our time together is just ours - it’s our own creation. It’s like, I’m in your dream and you’re in mine.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, what we’re doing this whole night shouldn’t officially be happening.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s why this feels so other-worldly. (a beat) But then, the morning comes and we turn into pumpkins.  35 58.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ahh. I don’t want to talk about the morning.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But at this point I think you’re supposed to produce the glass slipper and see if it fits. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are on a large docked boat, the Johann Strauss, that serves as a restaurant. They are sitting at a quiet outdo table on the bow of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And this older friend of mine said, at the birth of his child - it was a home birth and he was there helping out and everything - at that profound moment of birth, all he could think about was death. That he was seeing something experience life for the first time, struggling for breath, and knowing that it was going to die someday. He couldn't get it out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I think that’s why life is so interesting - because it’s going to end.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. Death ups the ante being alive.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s the same for us tonight, though. If we knew we were going to see each other next week, it would not be the same energy, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do you think we will see each other after tomorrow morning?  59.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I asked you.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I’m thinking how...I don’t know if I’m going to be in Europe again anytime soon. Are you coming to the U.S. For any reason? Celine puts her head down on the table, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I don’t want to get into the practical side of how we'd see each other again. Flying. Let’s be rational adults about this.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, uh, rational.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We should try something different. (a beat) It’s not so bad if tonight is our only night. Maybe it makes it really special.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, usually you exchange numbers and call each other once, maybe write each other once or twice...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And then the slow fizzle.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I hate that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: There was this famous writer - I don’t remember who - who said the ideal relationship was two intense years, with clean breaks, fresh starts, friends for life, something like that. It’s like if you knew your relationship had to end in two years, there would be no room for fighting or wasted time. There could be more love and appreciation for one another. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like, if everyone you met you knew was going to die at midnight, you would be a much more compassionate person. I mean, everyone’s going to die, but since no one knows when, there’s all the time in the world to be assholes to one another.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why do we think that relationships are supposed to last forever anyway, and that anything less is a failure? (a beat) But I hate the thought that we’re just these ships passing in the night. I think the only time I get depressed is when I feel that life is just this series of momentary connections. I mean, of all the people you’ve ever known, how many of them are still in your life in any way? What happened to all the people you grew up with? Miss Van Sickle, my bus driver in first grade - what’s she up to? What kind of life is she having? A wandering violin player has entered the room and is pla a waltz.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But for some people, there are no real good-byes. I think if you have a meaningful experience with someone else, a true communication, they are with you forever in a way. We are all a part of each other in ways we'll never know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So it’s a deal? We’ll die in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I think it’s the only way. I don’t want to cheapen what’s special about our time together. If we push for something more, it’s like we're trying to commodify ourselves or something.  36 61.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, no delusions. No projections. Let’s just make the rest of tonight great.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And it’1l be ours forever.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We should do some kind of special handshake or something.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. They do a sort of handshake and then watch the violin pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celine and Jesse walk down a fairly busy street near some nightclubs. They come across a crowd gathered around a wo dancing, and the rhythmic sound of finger cymbals can be heard. Sitting on the ground is a man playing a dumbek wh beats out a mesmerizing rhythm. Celine grabs Jesse’s arm with a look of excitement and rushes toward the crowd, finding a good vantage point to watch the Middle Eastern dancer. The dancer performs in an exciting and unusual wa and elicits a positive reaction from the crowd. At the en of the performance Celine places a couple of bills in the tambourine that sits on the sidewalk near the dancer’s sh Then she and Jesse proceed down the street as the crowd disperses. Celine is obviously moved by the dance.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I saw a documentary on that stuff - It’s a birth dance.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: A birth dance? How does that work?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Women used it when giving birth. In some parts of the world they still do it. The woman in labor enters a tent and the women of her tribe surround her and dance using their torsos and pelvises, and they encourage the birthing woman to dance with them so as to make the birth less painful. And after the baby is born, they all dance in celebration.  62.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wow. My mom would have never gone for that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But it’s a really primal dance. They think that women have usually done it mainly for other women as some kind of fertility ritual.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful thing. I like the idea of dance as being a common function of life, something that everyone participates in.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. I heard about this old man watching a bunch of young people dancing. He said, “How beautiful. They are trying to shake off their genitals and become angels.” (a beat) But, uh, just one question back there. When the women are being all spiritual and dancing for the gods and themselves and stuff, where are the men? Out food gathering? Just not allowed? See, Y'all don’t need us?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Men are lucky we don’t bite off their heads after mating. Certain insects do that, you know - spiders and stuff. We, at least, let you live. What are you complaining about? She laughs as he jumps on her words.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're officially kidding, but you keep bringing that up. There is something to that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No, no, no. Okay, speaking seriously here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, I feel this pressure to be a strong and independent icon of womanhood and not have it look like my life is only revolving around some guy, but the love of a man and returning that love means a lot to me. I always make fun of it and stuff, but isn’t everything we're doing in life a way to be loved a little more or something?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I dream of being a good father and a good husband. Sometimes that feels really close, but other times it just seems silly, and that it would ruin my life. It’s not that I have a fear of commitment or I’m incapable of loving or caring about someone else, because I can. It’s just that if I’m totally honest with myself, I’d rather die knowing that I was really good at something, that I was special or had excelled in some way, than to have only been in a really nice, caring relationship.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know, I had worked for this older man, and once he told me that he had spent all his life thinking about his career and his work, and how he was fifty-two and it suddenly struck him that he had never really given anything of himself, that his life was for no one and nothing. He was almost crying saying this. (a beat) I really believe that if there’s any kind of god, he wouldn’t be in any one of us - not you, not me - but just this space in between. If there’s some magic in this world, it must be in the attempt of understanding someone else, sharing something, even if it’s almost impossible to succeed. But who cares - the answer must be in the attempt.  37 38 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter a small, almost desolate disco where on couple dancing and a few others are sitting around - the up-all- night crowd. They split up and he goes over to the BARTEN and starts talking to him, pleading with him. She goes ov to an empty table and subtly takes two glasses. Across th room, he’s made a little headway with the gruff, older bartender, who eventually relents and hands him a bottle wine. Suddenly Lou Christie’s “Lightnin’ Strikes” comes o the speakers and Jesse hams it up as he crosses the dance floor on his way back to meet her at the door. He tries t get into it and has a little success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, they are sitting in a remote area of the park, pou glasses from their bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So often in my life I’ve been with people and shared beautiful moments like traveling or staying up all night and watching the sunrise, and I knew it was a special moment, but something was always wrong. I wished I'd been with someone else. I knew that what I was feeling - exactly what was so important to me - they didn’t understand. But I’m happy to be with you. You couldn’t possibly know why a night like this is so important to my life right now, but it is. I think this is a great morning.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It is a great morning. (a beat) Do you think we'd have other mornings like this?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What about our vow?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. (a beat) I've had those same feelings of wishing someone wasn’t there, but I think it’s myself I’d like to get away from.  She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve never been anywhere I haven’t been. I’ve never had a kiss when I wasn’t one of the kissers. I’ve never been to the movies when I wasn’t in the audience or gone out bowling when I wasn’t around making some stupid joke. She smiles, not really taking him seriously.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, really, I think that’s why so Many people hate themselves. I mean if we got married, after a few years, you'd hate a lot of my mannerisms, the way I drink a little too much when I’m insecure, the way I tell the same ridiculous, pseudo-intellectual ideas to every couple we have over to dinner. But you see, I’ve already heard all my stupid stories, so of course I’m sick of myself. But our time here has been completely out of time. Being with you has made me feel like I am someone else. I haven't had my past around to constantly drown me. The only other way to lose yourself like this is with drugs, or alcohol, dancing...stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Fucking... He just looks up at her, smiling, a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, fucking.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do you know what I want?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: To be kisses.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I can do that. 65.  66. He gets up and kisses her, and tries to take it a little further.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I have to say something stupid.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s very stupid.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don’t think we should sleep together. I want to, but since we're not going to see each other again, it’1ll make me feel bad. I‘’1l wonder who else you're with. I'll miss you. I know it’s not very adult...maybe it’s a female thing...I can’t help it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, we’ll see each other again.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. I don’t want you to break our vow just so you can get laid.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to just get laid. I want to have sex with you. We're going to die in the morning, right? I think we should.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. Then it’s like some male fantasy - meet a French girl on a train, fuck her, never see her again, and have a great story to tell. I don’t want to be a great story. I don’t want our great evening to have just been for that.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s not have sex.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to see me again?  39 67.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, of course I do. I mean, fuck, if I was asked right now to marry you or never see you again, I would Marry you. I mean, maybe that’s a lot of romantic crap. But people have gotten married for a lot less. I think we’d have as good a chance as anyone else. Do you want to sleep with me?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, actually I already decided to sleep with you when I got off the train. Now that we've talked so much I don’t know anymore. Why do I make everything so complicated?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. They begin making out as we see the first light in the sk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking along slowly, awkwardly, each a little i their own world.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What’s the first thing you’re going to do when you get back to Paris?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Call my parents. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I will go pick up my dog. He’s with a buddy of mine.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ahh. I love dogs.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, shit - we’re back in real time.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It’s awful. I can’t stand it. For the last few moments we’ve been hearing the sound of harpsichord far in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you hear that?  40 68.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah...What is that...a harpsichord?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Let’s go see where the hell that’s coming from. They walk toward the baroque sounds. As they get closer, music gets louder. They finally pinpoint the source. Through a small street-level window they see a guy ina basement room playing away at his harpsichord. The HARPSICHORD PLAYER’s entire room is decorated in a seventeenth-to eightenth-century fashion with wood-plank floors, old furniture, and paintings. Together with the beautiful and intense music, it is a stunning view - a li portrait. They sort of look at each other occasionally bu say nothing. Celine and Jesse both begin to feel awkward their Peeping Tom status now that the music is over, and walk off quietly. Jesse takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you dance to a harpsichord?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe. They dance a little on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit with their heads back on a bench, staring up at early-morning clouds.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: When you talked earlier about after a few years how a couple would begin to hate each other by anticipating their reactions or getting tired of their mannerisms, I think it would be the opposite with me. I think I can fall in love when I know everything about him - how he’s going to part his hair, or what shirt he’s going to wear that day, knowing the exact story he would tell in a given situation. I’m sure that’s when I'd know I’m really in love. Jesse just smiles, looks at her, and then slowly looks ba up at the sky.  4l 69.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (silly voice) The years shall run like rabbits...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I have this great recording of Dylan Thomas reading this W.H. Auden poem. He has this great voice. It was like... (silly voice) “But all the clocks in the city Began to whirr and chime: O let not Time deceive you, You cannot conquer Time... “In headaches and in worry Vaguely life leaks away, And Time will have his fancy To-morrow or to-day.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has retrieved her bag from the locker, and they are walking along the train toward her car. They seem vulnerable, even shy, as they both finally face the inevitable.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you know what bus you’re taking to the airport?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I guess this is it, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yep. I really...you know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. Me too. (a beat) You lied to me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  70.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You told me that our time together would someday make me happier with my future husband, but now I’11 wonder even more. Neither says anything for an extended moment.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be happy, okay? Work hard and have fun with everything you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I will. And good luck with school and everything. (a beat) I hate this.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. I think the train is about to leave. They look into each other’s eyes. Jesse reaches out for Celine’s hand and clasps it tightly. They smile, knowing that they’ve changed in unexpected ways, and then embrace tenderly for several moments. They part, and Celine turns suddenly and walks up the stairs to her train car. As she reaches the top step she hesitates, turns, and looks back Jesse, who's still staring at her. He signals for her to hold on a second.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hey, everything we were saying is bullshit. This is all stupid - I don’t want to do it. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I didn’t lie to you. I/’11 prove it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I‘11l come with you. Celine is almost laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. You'll drive me crazy. You don’t speak French. I’d have to completely take care of you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would be a big mistake. (a beat) But perhaps we should meet in five years.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, think so? Five years?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no. Five years is too long. It would be more like a sociology experiment. How about one year?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes, one year. One year? How about six months?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But it will be freezing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, we can meet here and then go somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. But is that six months from now or last night?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Last night. Okay. Six months from last night. December sixteenth, six o’clock in the evening, track eleven. It’s a train ride for you, but I got to fly over. But, hey, I’l1l be here.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Good. And we’re not going to write or call or anything right?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right. But six months. They laugh at themselves and give a quick kiss before parting.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bye. They part and Celine disappears into the train.  42 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celine finds her way to a seat. Jesse gets his stuff out his locker and begins walking. As her train slowly pulls of the station, we hear the harpsichord and see a series shots of many of the locations Celine and Jesse inhabited night before. In the early-morning light these places are now somehow different. Even though there is little human presence at this time of the morning, the transformation begun. We see Jesse getting situated on his bus to the airport. We then see the park where they danced, sang, an stared up at the sky. A very old lady walks slowly across the grass. Celine is settled on the train and reading. Sh looks up from her book and just stares out the window at landscape going by. FADE OUT.
